text_paragraphs: Information Note on the Court’s case-law No.
Administrative proceedings to challenge revocation of a tipping licence: no violation

[This summary is extracted from the Court’s official reports (Series A or Reports of Judgments and Decisions). Its formatting and structure may therefore differ from the Case-Law Information Note summaries.]
A.	Right of access to court
(a)	Constitutional Court: did not have requisite jurisdiction.

(b)	Administrative Court: nothing to suggest that limitations on its power of review, as relied on by applicant, were in issue in his case - regard being had to nature of applicant's complaints and to the scope of review necessitated by such complaints, Administrative Court's review fulfilled requirements of Article 6 § 1.
Conclusion: no violation (eight votes to one).

Section 39 (2) (6) of Administrative Court Act came into force in 1982, whereas Convention was ratified and reservation made in 1958 -no essential identity between section and provisions in force when reservation made - section not covered by Austria's reservation.
Applicant expressly requested oral hearing in Administrative Court - Administrative Court was first and only "tribunal" before which his case was brought.
Proceedings in question important for applicant's business existence: his right to a "public hearing" included an entitlement to an "oral hearing".
Claim for pecuniary loss resulting from revocation of licence -Court could not speculate as to outcome of proceedings had oral hearing taken place - claim rejected.
B.	Costs and expenses (in national courts and before Convention institutions): reimbursed on equitable basis.
Conclusion: respondent State to pay applicant specified sum (unanimously).
